DataElement.preferredName: Substance Extraction Intervention or Procedure Performed Study Activity Method Code ISO21090.CD.v1.0
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The completed action of extracting something from an associated study subject for the purpose of the extracted product to be administered to a study subject. EXAMPLE(S): A donor giving Bone Marrow Stem Cells for a Stem Cell Transplant NOTE(S): The study subject could be the same for the extraction and the intended administration. This is different than a performed specimen collection, in that the intent is different: This is a donation. A coded value specifying the technique that is used to perform the procedure. EXAMPLE(S): (1) Finger stick, veni puncture, Abdominal/ ascites effusion, Biopsy, Bronchial alveolar lavage (BAL) (for specimen collection); (2) Open, laparoscopic (for cholecystectomy).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Substance Extraction Intervention or Procedure Performed Study Activity Method Code
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any matter of defined composition that has discrete existence, whose origin may be biological, mineral or chemical.:The act of pulling out, including the process of obtaining something from a mixture or compound by chemical or physical or mechanical means.:An activity that produces an effect, or that is intended to alter the course of a disease in a patient or population. This is a general term that encompasses the medical, social, behavioral, and environmental acts that can have preventive, therapeutic, or palliative effects.:Executed and carried through to completion.:A detailed examination, analysis, or critical inspection of a subject designed to discover facts about it.:An active process; excludes processes and mechanisms which fulfill biological functions._A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.:A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.definition: Any matter of defined composition that has discrete existence, whose origin may be biological, mineral or chemical.
The act of pulling out, including the process of obtaining something from a mixture or compound by chemical or physical or mechanical means.

An activity that produces an effect, or that is intended to alter the course of a disease in a patient or population. This is a general term that encompasses the medical, social, behavioral, and environmental acts that can have preventive, therapeutic, or palliative effects.
Executed and carried through to completion.
A detailed examination, analysis, or critical inspection of a subject designed to discover facts about it.
An active process; excludes processes and mechanisms which fulfill biological functions.
